turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Imperial cult of ancient Rome.
turn.1: What was the downfall of Caligula?
turn.2: Caligula's rule exposed the legal and moral contradictions of the Augustan "Republic".
turn.3: what are some of the contradictions?
turn.4: To legalise his succession, the Senate was compelled to constitutionally define his role, but the rites and sacrifices to the living "genius" of the emperor already acknowledged his constitutionally unlimited powers.
turn.5: did the saety have any other problems?
turn.6: The "princeps" played the role of "primus inter pares" only through personal self-restraint and decorum.
turn.7: did the emperor have good leadership skills?
turn.8: It became evident that Caligula had little of either.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: He seems to have taken the cult of his own "genius" very seriously, and is said to have enjoyed acting the god – or rather, several of them.
turn.11: what several gods did he act as?
turn.12: However, his infamous and oft-cited impersonations of major deities may represent no more than his priesthood of their cults, a desire to shock and a penchant for triumphal dress or simply mental illness.
